title: 107_hr1916
content: The "21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001" includes a system for labeling violent content in audio and visual media products. The "21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001" establishes a system for labeling violent content in audio and visual media products, ensuring the public is informed about the nature and intensity of violence depicted in these products. The "21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001" establishes a system for labeling violent content in audio and visual media products to inform the public about the nature and intensity of violence depicted. The "21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001" introduces labeling for violent content in audio and visual media products to inform the public about depicted violence by minors of various ages. The "21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001" introduces labeling for violent content in audio and visual media products. The "21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001" allows manufacturers to propose a voluntary labeling system for violent content in various media products without antitrust law restrictions. The "21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001" permits a voluntary labeling system for violent content in media products, including interactive video games, without antitrust law restrictions. The labeling system must consider the nature, context, and intensity of violence in the product, assessing all depictions of violence comprehensively. The labeling system under the "21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001" requires specifying a minimum age for products or services based on the totality of violence depicted. Labels must include symbols and written text, be consistent across all products, and be prominently displayed on packaging. The labeling system under the "21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001" mandates clear labeling on products or services, including visual and audio elements, to be displayed before the product or service begins, and for at least five seconds. Advertisements must also include the appropriate labeling. Manufacturers can propose a labeling system to the Federal Trade Commission within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The 21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001 requires the Commission to review and issue a labeling system within 180 days. Manufacturers must submit a proposal for a labeling system to the Commission. The Commission will establish a labeling system if manufacturers fail to submit a proposal within the specified time. Regulations for the labeling system must be in place within one year of the Act's enactment. Starting a year after the Act, it is prohibited to sell or distribute certain media products without the required label. The 21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001 requires a labeling system for media products depicting violence, specifying a minimum age for purchasers. Starting a year after the Act, it is prohibited to sell certain media products without the required label. The Federal Trade Commission has the authority to investigate improper labeling of media products depicting violence under the 21st Century Media Responsibility Act of 2001. A civil penalty may be imposed for non-compliance with the labeling system. The Federal Trade Commission can impose a civil penalty for non-compliance with labeling requirements for media products depicting violence. Any person violating labeling requirements for media products depicting violence may face a civil penalty of up to $10,000 per violation. Each day of violation from the product's sale to the determination of the violation counts as a separate violation. Total liability is aggregated for all violations. The Act may be cited as the `Federal Cigarette and Media Violence Labeling and Advertising Act'.
